,d ,he bloody contest with their daring invaders,


have turned their face to the distant west, and with


a srh bid farewell to the rich vaes and hunting
grounds, where the bones of their fathers reposc-


4 new race now occupy their possessions, and the


wilderness is made to blossom as the rose. The


forest is thnned by the blows of the backwoodsman
villages and cultivated fields arise every side
1.-The land teens with population-thc rivers which
felt no weight before but the canoe of the warrior
fastening to battle, now covered with frcishts,


conveying the rich products of the west to market
canals and roads constructed for commercial
and friendly intercourse-halis of legislation and


Justice are erected for the government of this thriv-
ing people, and Colleges. Seminaries and Common


Schools are founded to dispense the treasure Of
cient and modern knowledge to their sous.


Such is the wonderful change that has passed un-
der the eve Of this sole delegate of the North
western Ter itorv in 1899. The territory which


he then represented is now cut up in the states OF
Ohio, Indiana and linois, and the Territory OF
Michigan-and leaving tract of country to the
northwest sufficient to form several more states
AT that time this district contained about fifty thou
sand inhabitants. The population at present is over
million and is represented in Congress by Eight
cen Representatives. six Senators and one Delegate
An advance similar to this in population, and i'm
provement, will perhaps never be witnessed again

houses. On that day, the atmosphere was filled
with fine misty rain, rendering il 50 dark as 10 make
lighe, candles necessary in our office. During the
night it became cold. and ice Of considerable thick
ness was formed. These harbngers Of dread Win
Ter are unusually early in their approach having ne
yer been witnessed by US SO soon in the season.
The leaves of the trees, not yet divested Of their
green hues presented rather unique appearance.
peeping from beneath their snowy mantle.


New YoRK, Nov 20.
INe Weather.-Winter has come at last in good
earnest. Sunday was cold rainy day and con-
siderable hail. and some snow, fell in the evening.
Yesterday morning the Mercury was within one or
two degrees Of the freezing point.


" Y. Com. .4dv.
rive have Winter here, too. There is no one
living, in this city, confident. who remem-
bers so severe spell Of weather in the month OF
November. We had considerable fall of snow on
Sunday last, and the weather since has gradually in
creased in coldness, until we now have the actual
severity of mid winter The ice in the Tiber IS an
inch thick and the Potomac is frozen nearly or
quite out to the channel.-Nat. hatN.1

OR1eINAL ANEcDorE.-Durng the rivalry be-
tween Utica and Rochester. gentleman merchant
from the latter place. was travelling through Oneida
County. Being Of a humorous turn, on passing a
Dutch dwelling where stone oven was heating,
which was situated out of doors, at side of the
house, he felt disposed to hoax the inhabitants He
called out hallo the house halo, the house ~
Out came the Dutchman, the Dutchman's wife, the
Dutchman's three sons, and the DutchnaDs eleven
daughters He observed to them ''your ovens on
fire. They all swiftly flew around the corner of
the house, and the merchant rode on enjoying
the ioke A short time since the same gentle
man was travelling to the east in gig the roads
we're uncommonly muddy. He was about passing


the same farm house, butbe had forgotten the place,
when young lad came running towards him, with
ureat anxiety depicted in his countenance. "Sr"
Said he. YOUR wheel is loose.'' The man imme-
dateiy got into tine mud and looked at the wheel,
when the boy exclams, ''the other wheel sir'
Around he waded through the mud, filled his pumps
with water and mire. examined the Inch pin there,
and saws to the boy do not any thing out Of
the way.v why thought twas loose" said the
lad. :. saw it turn round," (at the same time de-
scribiny circle with his finger. "You provoking
little rascal, what do you mean E'' exclaimed the
gentleman. 'Aye" says the lad the ovens on
FIRE the ovens on fre!'' The merchant was so
highly pleased with the lads wit that he threw him
dollar, and continued his journey.


| The editors of the New York Gazette have
ceived information, by the way OF Havana that Com
molore Porter has sailed for Caoz bay. with the
frigate Lbertad and the brig Guerrero, Doth well
mannet) with the view Of intercepting the frieate


pera. which sailed from Havana on the 10Th ut.


with $3.50 600 in gold The line of battle ship Sobra-
no is expected in Havana in all December, with 400


mariners for the garrison On the first of this


month the Spauish squadron at Havana, was busily


env,upd in bending their sails, &c. and appeared to
he. in every respect, in excellent order.

New YoRK ELEcTIoN-Ihe entire returns OF
the late election in the state of New York are pub
lished in the Albany and City papers. They differ
very widely in their estimate Of the relative strength
of Presidential parties among the members elect
The national Advocate gives the counties and their
delegates, in detail, and makes, from the best infor
nation it can obtain, the following hypothesis of
their political complexion:


In favor OF Mr.. Adams. So


In favor of Gen. Jackson, 46


Doubtful 27


The Advocate premises this statement with the
remark that it is '' difficult to give perfect list.
when the elections in the several counties have SO
generally been conducted without reference to that
question When the Jackson Editors disagree
among themselves as to the result in several coun-
ties, and many of the members refuse to commit
themselves on the subject of the Presidency, it is
impossible to say which party will have tine majority
in the House of Assembly. The Jackson candi-
dates for the Senate, adds the Advocate have sue
ceeded in six districts, in most cases Tor want OF
mnistration In the fourth and eight districts the
Administration candidates have succeeded by over
wheming majorities.''


In regard to illegal votes given at the election in
the city, the Advocate of Thursday last says, The
keeper of tavern and boarding house in Spring
street has called upon us and left his name, with
the name of an elector, and pledges himself to
prOve that the SAID eeCtOr VOeu the JacNsuh tich-
ct three times at the last election in this city,"


"Since writing the above, asenteman has called
and left the name of boy Of seventeen, who voted
the Jackson ticket and also of two men who reside
at the corner --, who voted during the cleo
ton in five different wards"


DUEL.-Extract of letter, dated Lincolnton
N. C. Nov. S.


81 have been informed Samuel P Carson latel,
challenged Dr. Robert B. Vance that they met or
Monday last, in Greenville district, and that DIR. u
Vance was killed, and Carson slightly wounded.


The following paragraph in relation to the above
unfortunate affair, is extracted from the Augusta
f Courier of the 10th instant.


son Monday last, on the Saluda Mountain, neal
the dividing line of North and South Carolina, Mr
Vance was shot through the body in duel with MIR
Carson. They were rival candidates for Congress
last August in North Carolina. Mr.. Carson ha
, becn successful in both contests. Mr. vance,
was supposed, had received mortal wound.


They were both heroites. The victor IS the re
tnowned author of the Billiard Table SANDER.

ginia, and have no doubt that IT wl'l soon per-

NOIiTH.CAROlLINA.

We have seen letter from Kent, stating that
she Governor, after mature deliberation, pardoned
Solomon Greenley on condition that he would leave
khe State within five days after his liberation from
hc charge of horse stealing. Greenley knew moth
ug of his pardon until the hour Of his execution ar
<iyed-In order to extort confession from him. his
tolin ant, buryng clothes were prepared and taken
nto his prison but he maintained and avowed his


innocence until the last moment, and disclosed facts
&vhich corroborated the fact of his innocence and
,duced the Sheriff to believe that he did not burn
he prison.


The Governor we understand was in Dover the


av previous to, and perhaps on the day OF the ap-
bonted execution What were the circumstances
which operated on his mind to grant the pardon, we
ave not heard bnt if the foregoing statement be
not erroneous, and we have reason to suppose 1t


30, it would be unnecessary to state others, however
numerous and weighty they might be.


English papers to Oct. 5, have been received at


New-York. Additional time had been given to the
Sultan, to decide on the propositions of the Euro
pean powers--viz--the IS Sept for the final an
swer Dispatches of great importance were re-


ceived in London from antlnople-reat'ng, II


was supposed, to the Egyptian fleet. The d'stur

posed to be exaggerated

things now stand, some of their enterprlsng citizen

and general prosperity springng up from judcio

the election Of General eksun. and friendly to the

We copy the following on the subject, from the
Raleigh Register, of Nnv. 13:


I'VE invite the attention Of the friends of the Ad-
minlstration to the notice contained in this days pa
per, calling public meeting in Carteret County. Tor
the purpose of appointing Delegates to meet in this
city, on the Goth Of December, ensuing, to form an
Electoral Ticket 1t is true. North Carolina voted
for General Jackson at the last Presidential Electon;
but it is equally true that the friends of Mr.. Adams
contributed largely to effect that object We con-
lidenty believe that. six moths ago, completely
was the empire of the public mind usurped by pas
sion and prejudice, that even truth itself would have
been found mpotent in contest with them. But
time, which effects revolution in all human affairs,
is working gradual change in public sentiment in
this State. The spells of military infatuaton are
losing their effect


----the charm dissolves apace,
And as the morning steals upon the night
Melting the darkness Their rising senses
Iegm to chase the ignorant fumes tnat mantle
Their clear reason.


The important developments which have taken
place since April last, in relation to the charge Of
corruption brought by Gen. Jackson, have greatly in
creased he friends Of Mr.. Adams. He has passed
through the ordeal uncontamnated. and has obtain
ell loftier elevation from the disgraceu attempts to
abase him. What may we not then expect during
the twelve months which will intervene before the
election9 Virginia. making great and magnani.
nous effort to obtain the triumph of learning and
virtue over the deusive glare of military enthusiasm,
and every indication is suspicious.


Two hundred and eighty five Swiss and French
emorants lately sailed from Havre for Buenos Ayres,
where they go to settle on land furnished by the gov
ernment.


The snow and ice had disappeared at Hallowel,
Maine, at the last accounts. About ten days since
the ground was covered with snow, and the river
filled with ice


COM. PORTER--The New York Daily Adver-
tiser SAYS seems to be very doubtful what is the
object Of this officer and whittier he has directed
his course --He lately disappeared from our south
ern coasts; and while some have conjectured that hs
was going to intercept Spanish vessel with money
bound from Havana to Cadz, others think he ha
: gone to assist in the protection OF Carhagena II
Colombia, against which, it rumoured, the Span
ish ships OF War in Havana were fitting out viii
such despatch.


Speaker of the House Of Represenfofices.-At
, tacks have been made on Mr.. TAYLOR, Speaker 0
the Ii. Of Representatives in the last Congress, a


Richmond, Washington, Philadelphia, and Albany
at the same time. This simultaneous fire merel
shows that the jackson forces well disciplined
r and wait for the word.


r. Boston Journal.

limited experience have we !:,own the public mind
rush so rstantaneonsIy, from one extreme to anoth
er--rom the most blind and bigoted aud tnrons OPP
position to the tariff and manufactures, to the gene
raj persuasion ofthelr indispensable necessity to re-
store the waning fortunes of the State. and the wish
to see Virginia at once engage in them. 1t is rare
to meet an intelligent mind that has not exchanged IFS
prejudices against manufactures for convictions OF
their utility and expediency. These convictions
have been forced upon the public by the sternest of
enthusiastically; by the contemplation of gen.
eral poverty and decay. The public mind is freed
from the prejutces SO long felt, SO ndustronsy To-
mented by certain politicians All that was ever
necessary to liberate it OF its bigotry, has been
complished-to bring 1t to The point Of inquiry. So
plain simple and conclusive is the reasoning which
proves the expediency of Virgina's engaging IN
mauufdctures-her natural advantages, her raw ma
teral, her water power, her coal mines, are so
abundant and inexhaustible--her future prosperity
is so obviously dependent upon her withdrawing
portion of her labor and capital from the overdone
and unproductive (unproductive because overdone)
pursuit of agrculture-tha to bring the public mind
to think on these subjects, was one and the same
thing AS to convince it that manufacturing was good
policy. We consider the struggle between preju-
dice and reason as already over--the contest was as
brief as the antagonists were unequal. Virginia is
about to become largely manufacturing state and



| few years be an advocate of the tariff.
| Our old friend Carter Beverly, has sadly failed
in his prosecution for libel.


! Mr. Carson, the reputed author of the billiard
Table SANDER, has killed Mr.. Vance in duel.


The papers, in every direction, speak Of the
weather as being unusua lily cold torthe season, & a
severe winter is anticipated by many of the weather
wise.


The Tennessee Legislature have discovered great
evils, and found the "surest remedy" for them :
namely that the measures of the administration are
not only bad, but very dangerous TO the Liberties Of
the country, and that Andrew Jackson alone, just
about this time is the only man who can recity mat
ters.


i These men, also, are men of much logic: for
thev have argued the corruption of Messrs Adams
and Clay in manner at least, satisfactory to them
selves.


i But-behold-when resolution offered in
structing the Tennessee members of Congress to
impeaeh Mr. Adams, and prefer the very charges
contained in the resolutions and argument passed
|
, or three only were found bold enough to vote fol


impeachment. They knew that it was one thin!
, to make accusations, and another to prove them
: They knew that these things might be published b,
violent partizan prints, and even resolved by Ten
G nessee Legislature: They knew that the General
at his fire side might say some very strange thing
it &C before all his company" which, in spite OF th
r. testimony ofhis own witness, would have some val


liable effects upon shallow pates and dunder heads


They knew that the Opposition tales, generally
1t though they had such disasterous fate, still
lie did some good to the cause, in certain instances
D. but to bring these charges before Congress- to max
n a serious matter of the business, to expose them
selves to contempt and rdicue, and, by their sgnt
1t failure to disgust and actually to open the eyes
+ those people who had been influenced by their az
p cusations, was a very different sort of busines


Gentlemen yon were not simply &C wise in yor


own conceit," but in the estimation of the public.
go The Knoxville Enquirer jackson print, says
N' /" Taking the whole of this business, from first
ny last, into dspassionate consideration, repeat, wi
az " fearless confidence, that our Legislature appears
'e Door advantage in the eyes of an enlightened cou
,a try'

BALTIMORE Nov. 90. .

On Friday evening last seal-skin hair trunk
which contained about S. 1000 in bank notes, was
stolen from on board the Steamboat COneteation OF
New York. reward of five hundred dollars is Of
fered for the recovery Of the property.

Honestu Wednesday last, the sum of fifteen
hundred dollars was lost in the street in Philadelphia
by lad, and the day following it was advertised,
and a liberal reward offered for its recovery. 1t
fortunately, was picked up by a poor but honest
porter whose stand was at the corner OF Front and
Market street, and promptly conveyed to the own
or.


A letter from the Secretary Of the Navy to O.
Wiswal Esq. of Hudson. states that it is probable
the remains Of the late and much iamented Lieut..
VIM. II. Allen, will shortly arrive at New York in
the U. s. schr. Grampus.
London n afer W0rks. New River Works
at Islington ''dscharge every twenty four hours
This exceeds the rate of SO 6hossheads every hour,
or l65 hogsheads every minute.

Every mail confirms our impressions that the re-
suit of the election in the state of New York; though
by no means as favorable to the cause Of Gen Jack
son as his advocates would have believe, was not
in consequence of the opinions of the people of that
state on the Presidential question. The Buckta'l
party, as usual, elected majority of their cand'-
dates and Bucktail generally voted for auckta'l'
leaving Jackson and Adams out of the ques-
ton in the state election. In national question
voting for presidential eectors-the case Will


be far otherwise, unless party discipline is more
pertect there than we have ever known it to be any
where. Notwithstanding, in designating his Buck
tail candidates, Mr.. Van Buren, deserves we'll OF
the Combination, and Jackson has the appearance
of strength in great state, decided majority OF
which is, in reality, opposed to him.

he prison.

not erroneous, and we have reason to suppose 1t

We copy the following on the subject, from the
Raleigh Register, of Nnv. 13:


I'VE invite the attention Of the friends of the Ad-
minlstration to the notice contained in this days pa
per, calling public meeting in Carteret County. Tor
the purpose of appointing Delegates to meet in this
city, on the Goth Of December, ensuing, to form an
Electoral Ticket 1t is true. North Carolina voted
for General Jackson at the last Presidential Electon;
but it is equally true that the friends of Mr.. Adams
contributed largely to effect that object We con-
lidenty believe that. six moths ago, completely
was the empire of the public mind usurped by pas
sion and prejudice, that even truth itself would have
been found mpotent in contest with them. But
time, which effects revolution in all human affairs,
is working gradual change in public sentiment in
this State. The spells of military infatuaton are
losing their effect


----the charm dissolves apace,
And as the morning steals upon the night
Melting the darkness Their rising senses
Iegm to chase the ignorant fumes tnat mantle
Their clear reason.


The important developments which have taken
place since April last, in relation to the charge Of
corruption brought by Gen. Jackson, have greatly in
creased he friends Of Mr.. Adams. He has passed
through the ordeal uncontamnated. and has obtain
ell loftier elevation from the disgraceu attempts to
abase him. What may we not then expect during
the twelve months which will intervene before the
election9 Virginia. making great and magnani.
nous effort to obtain the triumph of learning and
virtue over the deusive glare of military enthusiasm,
and every indication is suspicious.


Two hundred and eighty five Swiss and French
emorants lately sailed from Havre for Buenos Ayres,
where they go to settle on land furnished by the gov
ernment.


The snow and ice had disappeared at Hallowel,
Maine, at the last accounts. About ten days since
the ground was covered with snow, and the river
filled with ice


COM. PORTER--The New York Daily Adver-
tiser SAYS seems to be very doubtful what is the
object Of this officer and whittier he has directed
his course --He lately disappeared from our south
ern coasts; and while some have conjectured that hs
was going to intercept Spanish vessel with money
bound from Havana to Cadz, others think he ha
: gone to assist in the protection OF Carhagena II
Colombia, against which, it rumoured, the Span
ish ships OF War in Havana were fitting out viii
such despatch.

limited experience have we !:,own the public mind
rush so rstantaneonsIy, from one extreme to anoth
er--rom the most blind and bigoted aud tnrons OPP
position to the tariff and manufactures, to the gene
raj persuasion ofthelr indispensable necessity to re-
store the waning fortunes of the State. and the wish
to see Virginia at once engage in them. 1t is rare
to meet an intelligent mind that has not exchanged IFS
prejudices against manufactures for convictions OF
their utility and expediency. These convictions
have been forced upon the public by the sternest of
enthusiastically; by the contemplation of gen.
eral poverty and decay. The public mind is freed
from the prejutces SO long felt, SO ndustronsy To-
mented by certain politicians All that was ever
necessary to liberate it OF its bigotry, has been
complished-to bring 1t to The point Of inquiry. So
plain simple and conclusive is the reasoning which
proves the expediency of Virgina's engaging IN
mauufdctures-her natural advantages, her raw ma
teral, her water power, her coal mines, are so
abundant and inexhaustible--her future prosperity
is so obviously dependent upon her withdrawing
portion of her labor and capital from the overdone
and unproductive (unproductive because overdone)
pursuit of agrculture-tha to bring the public mind
to think on these subjects, was one and the same
thing AS to convince it that manufacturing was good
policy. We consider the struggle between preju-
dice and reason as already over--the contest was as
brief as the antagonists were unequal. Virginia is
about to become largely manufacturing state and



| few years be an advocate of the tariff.

in his prosecution for libel.

The Tennessee Legislature have discovered great
evils, and found the "surest remedy" for them :
namely that the measures of the administration are
not only bad, but very dangerous TO the Liberties Of
the country, and that Andrew Jackson alone, just
about this time is the only man who can recity mat
ters.


i These men, also, are men of much logic: for
thev have argued the corruption of Messrs Adams
and Clay in manner at least, satisfactory to them
selves.


i But-behold-when resolution offered in
structing the Tennessee members of Congress to
impeaeh Mr. Adams, and prefer the very charges
contained in the resolutions and argument passed
|
, or three only were found bold enough to vote fol


impeachment. They knew that it was one thin!
, to make accusations, and another to prove them
: They knew that these things might be published b,
violent partizan prints, and even resolved by Ten
G nessee Legislature: They knew that the General
at his fire side might say some very strange thing
it &C before all his company" which, in spite OF th
r. testimony ofhis own witness, would have some val


liable effects upon shallow pates and dunder heads


They knew that the Opposition tales, generally
1t though they had such disasterous fate, still
lie did some good to the cause, in certain instances
D. but to bring these charges before Congress- to max
n a serious matter of the business, to expose them
selves to contempt and rdicue, and, by their sgnt
1t failure to disgust and actually to open the eyes
+ those people who had been influenced by their az
p cusations, was a very different sort of busines

On Friday evening last seal-skin hair trunk
which contained about S. 1000 in bank notes, was
stolen from on board the Steamboat COneteation OF
New York. reward of five hundred dollars is Of
fered for the recovery Of the property.

Honestu Wednesday last, the sum of fifteen
hundred dollars was lost in the street in Philadelphia
by lad, and the day following it was advertised,
and a liberal reward offered for its recovery. 1t
fortunately, was picked up by a poor but honest
porter whose stand was at the corner OF Front and
Market street, and promptly conveyed to the own
or.

Every mail confirms our impressions that the re-
suit of the election in the state of New York; though
by no means as favorable to the cause Of Gen Jack
son as his advocates would have believe, was not
in consequence of the opinions of the people of that
state on the Presidential question. The Buckta'l
party, as usual, elected majority of their cand'-
dates and Bucktail generally voted for auckta'l'
leaving Jackson and Adams out of the ques-
ton in the state election. In national question
voting for presidential eectors-the case Will


be far otherwise, unless party discipline is more
pertect there than we have ever known it to be any
where. Notwithstanding, in designating his Buck
tail candidates, Mr.. Van Buren, deserves we'll OF
the Combination, and Jackson has the appearance
of strength in great state, decided majority OF
which is, in reality, opposed to him.
